descriptions.description: High-quality software with more features enhances the project's public perception and credibility.
A larger user base provides more testimonials and visibility, boosting the project's reputation.
More core developers increase the total workload for reviewing pull requests, extending the delay.
Longer review delays slow down the process of providing feedback on pull requests.
A higher volume of pull requests under review increases the total feedback being generated.
A larger base of implicit knowledge provides more material for experienced members to share via mentorship.
More core developers increase the capacity for mentorship and implicit knowledge transfer.
Constructive and timely feedback encourages newcomers to stay and become new contributors.
Effective feedback helps experienced contributors refine their skills and remain engaged.
Positive feedback and recognition through reviews motivates contributors to become core developers.
New contributors actively participating in reviews increase the total feedback being provided.
Experienced contributors provide more frequent and higher-quality feedback during reviews.
Providing feedback is an integral part of the review process for pull requests.
Well-documented explicit knowledge facilitates the creation of guides and documentation for newcomers.
Feedback from pull requests often contains valuable information that is archived in the knowledge base.
Resolved issues provide solutions and insights that are added to the searchable knowledge base.
A comprehensive knowledge base serves as a primary source for the project's explicit knowledge.
Community discussions generate questions and answers that enrich the searchable knowledge base.
A strong project reputation attracts more users to adopt and use the software.
More open issues generate more user reports, questions, and thus community feedback.
Community feedback often identifies new problems or details, leading to more open issues.
A healthy, collaborative community fosters a positive public image, enhancing project reputation.
Good documentation lowers the barrier to entry, increasing the rate at which newcomers join.
An effective governance strategy makes the project more attractive, encouraging newcomers to join.
A clear governance strategy streamlines onboarding, directly increasing the contributor joining rate.
High project reputation attracts more potential contributors, increasing the joining rate.
More maintainer time dedicated to issues accelerates the rate at which they are resolved.
Resolving issues moves them from an open to a closed state, increasing the stock of closed issues.
The creation of new issues, from users or developers, adds to the stock of open issues.
Resolving issues removes them from the open queue, decreasing the stock of open issues.
A larger and more complex codebase tends to generate more bugs and feature requests (issues).
Positive project activities and outcomes build up and enhance the project's reputation over time.
Negative events or stagnation erodes community trust and diminishes the project's reputation.
As knowledge is internalized and becomes implicit, it is no longer tracked as explicit documentation.
The process of documenting new discoveries and solutions adds to the project's explicit knowledge.
New users discovering and starting to use the software increases the total user base.
Users stopping their use of the software decreases the total user base.
Merging or committing a pull request removes it from the pool of requests under review.
Rejecting a pull request removes it from the review queue, decreasing the stock under review.
Initiating the review process on a new pull request adds it to the stock under review.
Merging approved pull requests adds new code and features to the main source code repository.
Access to good documentation helps contributors learn and advance their skills more quickly.
Direct mentorship accelerates learning and skill development for contributors.
Active community engagement in forums and chats produces content for the knowledge base.
Open issues often represent bugs or features that developers address by creating new pull requests.
The submission of new pull requests adds to the stock of new pull requests awaiting initial review.
Starting the review on a new pull request moves it out of the 'new' queue.
Core developers leaving the project reduces the number of active core developers.
Promoting experienced contributors to core developer status increases the core developer stock.
Effective mentorship prepares and qualifies experienced contributors for promotion to core developers.
When developers leave, their unique, undocumented knowledge is lost from the project.
Promoting an experienced contributor to core developer removes them from the experienced contributor stock.
As contributors improve their skills, they graduate from new to experienced status.
New contributors joining the project increases the stock of new contributors.
As new contributors skill up, they move out of the 'new' category into 'experienced'.
Developer turnover causes the loss of tacit knowledge held by those individuals.
As contributors internalize explicit knowledge through practice, it becomes part of the project's implicit knowledge.
The process of converting implicit knowledge into explicit form reduces the stock of purely implicit knowledge.
Negative interactions and burnout erode collaborative norms and degrade the community's health.
Positive interactions and successful collaboration build trust and strengthen the community's health.
